posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14353425
>only learned to write, farm, and record history all just 5000 years ago?
They learned to farm over twice that long ago. Early farming was not that great a benefit, its not even clear why they started as it took a lot of extra labor compared to hunter gathering. Eventually however the settlements became dependent on it when there were too many people for hunter gather lifestyles to support. Nevertheless many early farming settlements were abandoned because the people went back to hunter gathering.
Written language too took thousands of years. Early writing systems didn't do complete sentences, they were just things like names so people could keep track of their own property. There was little use for writing until people started having so much personal property they needed help keeping track of it. A scribe needs other people to get their food for them, its a huge social cost to have a dedicated class of literati. Early history records were just ledgers of who owed what to the king, letters between kings and inscriptions were kings bragged about how great they were.
>This is where evolution loses me
this has nothing to do with evolution. All if it happened after modern humans appeared. If God just put modern humans on Earth fully formed it wouldn't change the economics of civilization. Until you have thousands of people living in a single place that nature cannot support you will not get a complex civilization. A hunter gatherer has no short term motive to switch their lifestyle even if they do know how.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14353772
Abiogenesis is separate from evolution and yes, the research in that field is not nearly as complete, there are a few misconceptions here.
The line between non-life and life is not as clear as most imagine. Its debatable if viruses are "alive" for example. We have examples of self replicating chemistry in nature, which is the core of life, and we have example of cell like membranes. We don't know exactly how it started more so because there are several chemically viable possibilities. The earth is very different from what it was in its early days though and even lf life formed that way today, it could not compete with modern microscopic life. Lastly the vast majority of research in this field is not focused on recreating it in a lab, since creating new proto-life in a lab would not tell us how and if it happened in nature.

Incorrect dating methods due to Herodotus claiming that Egypt's dynasties are the most ancient. Thus, historians looked at Pharaohs' contemporaries and dated them to match this or that Pharaoh. >>14354476
The problem people make in judging God's goodness is that they say "pain = bad" and that's as far as their depth goes into the subject. So if anyone ever got an ouchie before, then God is evil.

But pain is a natural human bodily reaction, and a cautionary sign that you are in trouble and should seek some kind of help. That's why fire burns, because you got too close to it--if we couldn't feel pain, like some kind of leper, then we would go to sleep on a bed of coals and wake up dead after being immolated in fire that we could not sense.

In the same way Christians spurn lust, and wrath, and envy, they should want to spurn pain--not the pain itself, but their reaction to it. Christians cannot control if they feel lustful towards someone, or if they feel angry, or envious... but they can control their actions and reactions to those feelings. That's free will--what separates man from the soulless beasts that act only on instinct.

Even Jesus had his moment on the cross where he asked God why he had forsaken him, but he didn't let the pain undo him and cause him to damn God or cause him to lose his belief. He endured his pain, and he even comforted the thief who asked for forgiveness of his sins. And Jesus' last words before his death were to God, commending his spirit to Him and to Heaven. He survived the pain, his soul persisted.

The greatest mistake people make about this subject is to say that all those with disabilities or defects (or other poor life situations) are "suffering". And more often than not if you ask these people if they're happy... if they enjoy their life... if they find comfort in things around them, they'll tell you they do. It is only those who truly hate their own lives (often without reason) that believe those lesser than them must despise being alive. And I pity those people. And I pray for them.

>Lower Galilee, where Jesus lived most of His life, was Israel’s lushest region, known for its sunny, temperate climate and its spring-watered lands. Each spring, the valleys and slopes became an ocean of wildflowers and blossoming trees. Beginning in March, the area was covered by a vast blanket of green. The fertile land was a texture of vineyards and fruit orchards. Grapes, figs, olives, pomegranates, oranges, and other fruits flourished in its pleasant, subtropical climate.

>The first century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus, who knew the area well, wrote this about it:

>Its nature is wonderful as well as its beauty; its soil is so fruitful that all sorts of trees can grow upon it, and the inhabitants accordingly plant all sorts of trees there; for the temper of the air is so well mixed, that it agrees very well with those several sorts, particularly walnuts, which require the coldest air, flourish there in vast plenty; there are palm trees also, which grow best in hot air; fig trees also and olives grow near them, which yet require an air that is more temperate. One may call this place the ambition of nature, where it forces those plants that are naturally enemies to one another to agree together; it is a happy contention of the seasons, as if every one of them laid claim to this country; for it not only nourishes different sorts of autumnal fruit beyond men’s expectation, but preserves them a great while; it supplies men with the principal fruits, with grapes and figs continually, during ten months of the year and the rest of the fruits as they become ripe together through the whole year (The Jewish War, Book 3, Chapter 10:8).

>>14356035
> So where does this bizarre custom of decorating trees come from, if it does not come from pre-Christian paganism? Well, the earliest known reference to a Christmas tree is a depiction of one from a sculpture on the keystone of a private home located in Turckheim, France dating to 1576. If we assume that the custom was around for roughly fifty years or so before it was mentioned or depicted anywhere, that would indicate that the very first Christmas trees probably appeared in western Europe in the early 1500s. Christmas trees seem to have most likely originated from the “tree of Paradise,” that is, the tree used in late medieval mystery plays to represent the tree that Adam and Eve are said to have eaten from the Garden of Eden.

> The Christmas tree does not seem to have become popular, though, until the eighteenth century, at first mostly among affluent German Lutherans. The earliest known Christmas trees were decorated with nuts, berries, and other small, edible foods (as tree of paradise in the bible might have been). These nuts and berries were later replaced by ornaments and candles. There is a tradition claiming that Martin Luther himself was the first person ever to decorate a Christmas tree using candles, but there is no historical record to vindicate this tradition and it is most likely apocryphal.

> Modern Christmas trees have been related to the "tree of paradise" of medieval mystery plays that were given on 24 December, the commemoration and name day of Adam and Eve in various countries. In such plays, a tree decorated with apples (to represent the forbidden fruit) and wafers (to represent the Eucharist and redemption) was used as a setting for the play. Like the Christmas crib, the Paradise tree was later placed in homes. The apples were replaced by round objects such as shiny red balls.[13][14][19][20][21][22]

Genuinely, I'm not even trying to pull some kind of fast one on Marx, because I get the sense a lot of Marxists feel like that is what is happening when you historical Marxism as in the Christian tradition, but Christianity was central to Marx's philosophical development. Hegel was a Christian and his philosophy was heavily tied to his Christianity. Marx got involved with the Young Hegelians while he was in university, his dissertation was a critique of theology and his advisor was Bauer, who he addressed On the Jewish Question to. He comes out of university and spends a bunch of time basically critiquing religion while also getting involved in secular politics via his journalism. He was critiquing idealism and religion as a consequence of his rejection of the reality of their claims to the values he held, which were fundamentally Christian ones of universal salvation and brotherhood etc. And that ultimately led him to the doorstep of political economy because it was another edifice that the liberals of his day used to uphold bourgeois class society. So he goes at length to suggest the ways that the categories and thought of liberal political economy continues to reproduce a world that is not as "rational" or even "secular" as they seemed to believe. But these are all a series of theological disputes in a Christian tradition about who the universal subject of salvation is, what it means to be saved, what is history moving towards etc.

>I cannot attempt to summarise my book in this brief talk. But I want to tell you about a few of the biographical features that have struck me while I have been working on my book, even though I have closely watched Stalin’s career for more than twenty years.

>Stalin is the son of emancipated serfs. The emancipation of the peasants in Georgia, his native land, took place in 1865, only fourteen years before his birth. The customs and habits of the environment in which he grew up bore deep and still fresh imprints of serfdom. This is certainly one of the clues to his character. Remember that in this country serfdom had virtually withered away by the end of the fourteenth century. By British standards, Stalin ought to be regarded as a man in whom the fourteenth and the twentieth centuries have met, socially, politically and psychologically. In this respect he has, more than any other Russian leader, been representative of the social outlook of Russia, in which the two centuries did coexist side by side until recently. This was certainly one of the chief reasons why he was so successful in the struggle against so many rivals and also why his deeds so often appear to us to be so incomprehensible.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14351866
>He spent his formative years, from fifteen to twenty, at the theological seminary of Tiflis, as a student of divinity. Long after he had become a confirmed atheist, the theological influence on his mind was still overwhelming. It still is. It was that influence that in a sense predestined him to introduce the dogmatic, quasi-theological element into socialism. While he was studying divinity he became a revolutionary. I have been lucky to come across a complete dossier of the Tsarist political police, describing the political atmosphere in that seminary over a good many years. The dossier was published by the Transcaucasian Communist University in 1930; but it has remained almost unknown. It contains a full confidential report on a political revolt of the students of the seminary which took place just before Stalin’s entry. The students staged a strike, demanding that they be taught Georgian literature – this was a Georgian challenge to the Russian authorities – and that several unpopular tutors be removed from the seminary. Teaching was suspended, police occupied the students’ living quarters and the lecture halls. Eighty-seven undergraduates were expelled from the seminary altogether. Among the organisers of the demonstration was a certain Mikhail Tskhakaya who later became a friend of Lenin and a member of the Bolshevik Central Committee. The seminary was famous for the rebellious mood of its pupils, which at first expressed itself in Georgian patriotism, directed against the Russians, and then simply in socialism. I found in the reports of General Yankovsky, the head of the police at Tiflis, a most valuable glimpse of a spiritual ferment which could not but affect the young Stalin.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14353536
This was pretty regular in the Warlord Period, especially in the lower ranks. Unlike the "10 Gorrillion" memes, it was actually pretty ok to be a soldier in the time. Sure there was lots of fighting around but not only were you the only faggot with a salary in China but even when your side lost, the winning side is more than willing to absorb you for their own army. Soldiers were seen as such a precious manpower resource that you'll be assuredly treated well in any army.

In fact there were almost no POWs in the Warlord Period. Prisoners were often convinced to join their captors army (usually with a double first month salary) and they did.

A young soldier living in 1920s China might end up fighting for a warlord, defecting to the KMT in 1927, fight communists, get abandoned in the North in 1935, get picked up by Communist Guerrillas from 1941-45, and end his days as a veteran of the PLA by the end of 1949.

>China was one person in a greentext
Chinese people wanted to trade freely with the outside world but the Qing dynasty throttled trade to keep it under their control and impose their heavy taxes and duties, basically a giant extortion racket. The bureaucratic Empire couldn't have stood more in contrast to the free trade obsessed British and entrepreneurial East India Company which held that a rising tide floated all boats, this culminated in the Napier affair after the British stood up for the Chinese people and requested they open the ports to which the Qing refused to negotiate.

A few years later the Qing suddenly took a tough stance against a plant which had been traded for decades with no complaints from Canton. The Qing began boarding ships and destroying property without warning, this led to a series of escalations as the British stood their ground and asserted their rights while the Qing having to save face and the rest is history. The Qing were in the wrong, but their actions were understandable, they were an ancient "middle Kingdom" and their soldiers were told they were fighting to defend their country, it was a struggle between 2 powers who were bound by duty.

To the 21st century mind it was "colonialism" which is considered the worst evil in the world, but how does it compare exactly to the Qing exploitation of Chinese peasants? They were an "authoritarian regime" after all. To the 19th century mind it was more like a beef between 2 mafia families in terms of morality, acts of human folly on both sides which only the most ascetic monks truly escape from, though perhaps the British had a slight upper hand since it brought China out of the dark age. The mercantile people of Guangzhou and Shanghai would prosper and they would rise from poverty to a middle class level of wealth until the Japs arrived and made the British look like puppies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The “purpose” of life isn’t to reproduce or prolong the species. This just happens to be one of the primary desires, and “meaning” comes from desire and preference. When you’re starving, you don’t ask yourself the “meaning” of eating. You just know that you want to fucking eat. And by the way, since we feel hunger and eat more than we have sex, it would make more sense to say that the purpose of life is to eat rather than reproduce, or simply stay alive for as long as possible. But of course it’s absurdly reductive to ask for a single “purpose” to life. We exist with all our desires simply because they happened to lead to reproductive success. To ask about the meaning of life is like asking what your desires are, but you ALREADY know this, fucktard. Of course the only real problem is how to live the best possible life, that is, to satisfy your preferences. And here some will say “there is no correct way to live,” but we know that this is partially bullshit because there certainly are better ways to live. In general, whatever makes you more powerful will lead to more satisfaction. Financial power, physical power, social power, etc. Not only do these things inherently provide a feeling of health and happiness, but they allow you to better attain any desire that you may have.

This whole issue is mostly semantics, as usual. As emotional beings everything eventually comes down to preference and desire. It makes no sense to talk about an “objective” purpose to life. You have your subjective desires, it is up to you to satisfy them. Depressed losers can’t do this so they just say life is meaningless.

North Africa is nowhere on the Eurasian continent and the Middle East is not Western Eurasia, the Middle East is the Middle East.

And in any event you're splitting hairs. These were not politically unified races of peoples and culturally only shared certain similarities where in practice those marginal differences could be extremely pronounced like the difference between Israelites and Canaanites and lead to extended blood feuding. Individual city-states could have bitter, long standing rivalries and have long histories of independence and struggle against each other, and even vague attempts at some kind of ethnic hegemony like Athens attempt at building a pan-hellenic league encountered bitter resistance every step of the way until they even went so far as to sell out to foreigners in order to prevent it from happening.

When the Romans conquered or absorbed these places they stopped feuding with each other and became part of a vast economic machine that could ship goods and services all over the empire, with massively deep and interconnected supply chains that could result in cash crops grown in Egypt sold to producers in Asia Minor to be processed into goods being shipped and sold in Britannic markets, with trade routes so peaceful that cities no longer needed walls. They gained peace and prosperity but in return sacrificed the things that made them unique from their neighbors and culturally everyone blobbed together and lost their traditional cultures. If that's not globohomo, what is?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14353854

Chancellorsville was arguably his best shot. At the end of the second day, the XI Corps was effectively routed and a substantial portion of the Union Army was in danger of becoming trapped in an extremely small pocket with no way of getting out. Only Sickles (yes, THAT Sickles) and III Corps kept the escape route open. If Jackson hadn't been wounded and pressed his attack into the night and the following day, Sickles' positions might have very well collapsed, leaving tens of thousands of Union troops trapped in a Stalingrad-like cauldron. Assuming the Confederates could annihilate the pocket like the Soviets did the 6th Army 80 years later, it would have left the Army of the Potomac incapable of further combat operations, or essentially operationally destroyed.

Now would this have ended the war in a Confederate victory? Well, not necessarily. Even with the Army of the Potomac out of the fight, this wouldn't have changed the situation in the West, which was far more dire. But the destruction of its premier field army would have likely forced Washington DC to cancel further offensives in the West so Union forces would be redeployed to help regenerate the Army of the Potomac (and prevent Confederate troops from invading the North with impunity). Prizes like Vicksburg might've been taken off the table, or at the very least had their capture postponed considerably.

>>14354805
>The Roman system was probably superior, they shunned monarchy and so Emperors would designate their successor, they avoided Emperors being cloistered in the palace with eunuchs and concubines like the Ottomans and Chinese.

It really isn't. The Roman System was quite unstable for the first half of the Empire specifically because the Emperor was not considered a legitimate monarch but a strong military dictator. Their legitimacy doesn't lay in the dynasty of the Emperor but how strong EACH individual emperor is, how in command of "imperium" they are. The designated successor CONSISTENTLY has to prove himself personally worthy and thus gets always subjected to challenges to his power. Leading to many fucking succession wars in Rome's history.

In contrast the Chinese Dynastic system imbues legitimacy upon the ENTIRE Dynasty, not just one person. So long as the Dynasty as a whole- its government, its military, its everything- works fine, it doesn't matter if the Emperor is a genius or a moron, the Dynasty is legitimate. Hence succession is seldomly question and when it does, succession disputes within the Dynasty barely go beyond palace stabbings and passive-aggressive bullshit contests between concubines & heirs, while the court goes about its business administrating the realm. Although a Dynasty that regularly squabbles with itself did invite rebellion by other power brokers who see disunity = loss of the Mandate of Heaven.

In fact compared to Rome, China had only 3 succession wars in its history (War of the 8 Princes, Tang Interregnum, Zhu Di's Revolt).

Read some Ed Siecienski, he is the foremost scholar on the schism today. This isn’t an issue that is solved by producing patristic florilegia. East and West had fundamentally different ecclesiologies and the schism never happened all at once, it began slowly and gradually centuries before it was definitive. If one looks into what many of the Orthodox criticisms of the West were, it was oftentimes not even mainly aimed at the papacy itself until the later periods, but they would attack the West for things such as beardless clergy, unleavened bread (calling them judaizers for doing so), and for the filioque of course, which was taught for centuries prior to the controversy in the West and is even affirmed by many saints recognized by EO today. Many of these are petty concerns that should never have been roadblocks to unity. The East often acted rather tsundere towards Rome too. When things were falling apart in the East with renewed outbreaks of heresy, Eastern bishops and the emperor would praise Rome in some of the highest terms possible, but in other times of stability be at odds with Rome. Not even a papist, I agree with EO more than anything, but there’s some flaws.

>>14354798
Peter definitely seems to have been given some sort of special role. I think trying to read Matthew 16 as not saying that as at least one of its possible meanings is always a bit of a stretch (for example many say that it is *just* Peter’s faith that Christ is referring to). We also see evidence pretty early on that attests to the high position of Rome in the early Church, such as what Irenaeus wrote in Against Heresies, perhaps also Clement’s letter to Corinth, and things such as the *attempted* actions of Pope Victor against the churches of Asia. The fact that Rome was given essentially universal appellate jurisdiction in the Council of Sardica is pretty interesting as well. The idea that the Apostolic See was *merely* first among equals and that this meant really nothing at all but honor seems dubious. John Chrysostom wrote that James was the bishop of Jerusalem, while Peter was given as a teacher for the whole world. Examples of this could be multiplied. The exclamations that ‘Peter spoke through Leo!’ or ‘Agatho’ in some of the ecumenical councils by the Fathers is also interesting. I think history is a bit murkier than made out to be. I think it was interesting that Erick Ybarra kind of admits this in his new book on the papacy, while saying it ultimately supports Catholicism more.

In the ethnically diverse court entourage, jewelry was influenced by far away Iran. The gold filigree ornaments with turquoise-colored insets found in the tomb of an official called Shi Gang are derived from Iranian models.
